pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:0.2: The nuns’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:0.6: Venerables, these one hundred and sixty-six rules on offenses entailing confession come up for recitation.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.2: At that time a lay disciple had invited the Sangha of nuns to ask for garlic:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.3: “If any of the nuns need garlic, I’ll supply it.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.4: And he had told his field-keeper,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.5: “If the nuns come, give two or three bulbs to each nun.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.6: On that occasion a festival was being held in Sāvatthī,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.7: and the garlic was used up as soon as it arrived there.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.8: Just then the nuns went to that lay follower and said,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.11: As soon as the garlic arrives, it’s used up.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.13: The nun Thullanandā went to the field, and not having any sense of moderation she took a large amount of garlic.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.14: The field-keeper complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.15: “How could the nuns not have any sense of moderation and take a large amount of garlic?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.16: The nuns heard the complaints of that field-keeper,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.17: and the nuns of few desires complained and criticized her,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.18: “How could Venerable Thullanandā not have any sense of moderation and take a large amount of garlic?” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.19: “Is it true, monks, that the nun Thullanandā did this?”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.22: “How could the nun Thullanandā not have any sense of moderation and take a large amount of garlic?
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.23: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.24: and after giving a teaching he addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.25: “At one time, monks, Thullanandā was the wife of a brahmin.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.28: Then, when that brahmin had died, he was reborn as a goose.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.29: His feathers were all made of gold,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.30: and he gave them one feather each.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.31: After thinking about this, Thullanandā took hold of that king of geese and plucked him.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.32: But when his feathers regrew they were white.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.33: At that time, monks, Thullanandā lost her gold because of too much greed.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.34: Now she will lose her garlic.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.35: One should be content with what one gets,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.37: After taking hold of the king of geese,
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.38: The gold came to an end.”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.39: Then, after rebuking the nun Thullanandā in many ways for being difficult to support …
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.40: the Buddha said, “And, monks, the nuns should recite this training rule thus:
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:1.41: ‘If a nun eats garlic, she commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.1.4: … The nun who has been given the full ordination by both complete Sanghas through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of nun is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.1.6: from Magadha is what is meant.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.1.7: If she receives it with the intention of eating it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.1.8: For every mouthful, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.2.1: If it is garlic and she perceives it as garlic, and she eats it, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.2.2: If it is garlic, but she is unsure if it is, and she eats it, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.2.3: If it is garlic, but she does not perceive it as garlic, and she eats it, she commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.2.4: If it is not garlic, but she perceives it as garlic, and she eats it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.2.5: If it is not garlic, but she is unsure of it, and she eats it, she commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.2.6: If it is not garlic and she does not perceive it as garlic, and she eats it, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.3.6: if it is cooked in a bean curry;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.3.7: if it is cooked with meat;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.3.8: if it is cooked with oil;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.3.10: if it is a special curry;
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.3.12: if she is the first offender.
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1:2.3.13: The first rule, the training rule on garlic, is finished.
